subject: Re: [junit] black box or white box?
msgSnippet: ... the ... second ... to ... that ... work. ... Test theory says that s not possible in the general case. Binder [Binder00] calls that the antiextensionality
messageBody:
> > When your tests only use the public interfaces they usually don't
> > break
> > during refactoring. They might become redundant, i.e. worthless, when
> > you
> > test a special case which is no special case in the new refactored
> > implementation any more.
>
> Redundant is *not* worthless in this case! If you refactor again, later,
the
> redundant tests may no longer be redundant. That was the thrust of this
second
> point: it's not enough to cover the current implementation, one must try
to
> cover the problem with one's tests. The idea is to have a set of tests
that
> would indicate whether any reasonable implementation of the feature would
work.
> I'm not saying that this is easy.

Test theory says that's not possible in the general case. Binder [Binder00]
calls that the antiextensionality axiom. He states "that a test suite that
covers one implementation of a specification does not necessarily cover a
different implementation of the same specification".

I interpret "not necessarily" as "there's no such thing in the general
case". One short example which is hopefully obvious enough this time.
Consider a function for sorting an array of String objects:

public String[] sort(String[] unsortedStrings) {
if (unsortedStrings.length < 20) {
return bubblesort(unsortedStrings);
} else {
return quicksort(unsortedStrings);
}
}

To have a test case with reasonable coverage you have to do (at least) two
tests:
- Sorting 19 (or less) String objects
- Sorting 20 (or more) String objects

Now performance considerations lead to a changed implementaion:

public String[] sort(String[] unsortedStrings) {
if (unsortedStrings.length < 20) {
return bubblesort(unsortedStrings);
} else if (unsortedStrings.length < 100) {
return quicksort(unsortedStrings);
} else {
return mergesort(unsortedStrings);
}
}

For good coverage you now have to add another test case: sort 100 or more
String objects. How big is the test suite which covers any reasonable
implementation? Do you have to test any number of String objects from 0 to
whatever? BTW, the AE axiom is one (of many) reasons why functional
(specification-based) tests alone are not enough. IMO we need
implementation-aware tests to go beyond a certain level of quality.

Johannes

[Binder00] Robert V. Binder: Testing Object-Oriented Systems
